And brought your prisoner to your palace gate.

sp.speaker: King Edward
sp.l: See that he be conveyed unto the Tower:
And go we, brothers, to the man that took him,
To question of his apprehension.
Widow, go you along. Lords, use her honourably. Exeunt all but Gloucester.

sp.speaker: Gloucester
sp.l: Ay, Edward will use women honourably.
Would he were wasted, marrow bones and all,
That from his loins no hopeful branch may spring,
To cross me from the golden time I look for!
And yet, between my soul's desire and me —
The lustful Edward's title buried —
Is Clarence, Henry, and his son young Edward,
And all the unlooked-for issue of their bodies,
To take their rooms, ere I can place myself:
A cold premeditation for my purpose!
Why, then, I do but dream on sovereignty;
Like one that stands upon a promontory,
And spies a far-off shore where he would tread,
Wishing his foot were equal with his eye,
And chides the sea that sunders him from thence,
Saying, he'll lade it dry to have his way:
So do I wish the crown, being so far off;
And so I chide the means that keeps me from it;
And so I say, I'll cut the causes off,
Flattering me with impossibilities.
My eye's too quick, my heart o'erweens too much,
Unless my hand and strength could equal them.
Well, say there is no kingdom then for Richard;
What other pleasure can the world afford?
I'll make my heaven in a lady's lap,
And deck my body in gay ornaments,
And witch sweet ladies with my words and looks.
O miserable thought! and more unlikely
Than to accomplish twenty golden crowns!
Why, love forswore me in my mother's womb:
And, for I should not deal in her soft laws,
She did corrupt frail nature with some bribe,
To shrink mine arm up like a withered shrub;
To make an envious mountain on my back,
Where sits deformity to mock my body;
To shape my legs of an unequal size;
To disproportion me in every part,
Like to a chaos, or an unlicked bear-whelp
That carries no impression like the dam.
And am I then a man to be beloved?
O monstrous fault, to harbour such a thought!
Then, since this earth affords no joy to me,
But to command, to check, to o'erbear such
As are of better person than myself,
I'll make my heaven to dream upon the crown,
And, whiles I live, to account this world but hell,
Until my misshaped trunk that bears this head
Be round impaled with a glorious crown.
And yet I know not how to get the crown,
For many lives stand between me and home:
And I, — like one lost in a thorny wood,
That rents the thorns and is rent with the thorns,
Seeking a way and straying from the way;
Not knowing how to find the open air,
But toiling desperately to find it out, —
Torment myself to catch the English crown:
And from that torment I will free myself,
Or hew my way out with a bloody axe.
Why, I can smile, and murder whiles I smile,
And cry “Content” to that which grieves my heart,
And wet my cheeks with artificial tears,
And frame my face to all occasions.
I'll drown more sailors than the mermaid shall;
I'll slay more gazers than the basilisk;
I'll play the orator as well as Nestor,
Deceive more slily than Ulysses could,
And, like a Sinon, take another Troy.
I can add colours to the chameleon,
Change shapes with Proteus for advantages,
And set the murderous Machiavel to school.
Can I do this, and cannot get a crown?
Tut, were it farther off, I'll pluck it down. Exit.

div.head: Act 3, Scene 3
div.stage: Enter LEWIS the French King, his sister BONA, his Admiral, called BOURBON: PRINCE EDWARD, QUEEN MARGARET, and the EARL OF OXFORD. LEWIS sits, and riseth up again.

sp.speaker: Lewis XI
sp.l: Fair Queen of England, worthy Margaret,
Sit down with us: it ill befits thy state
And birth, that thou shouldst stand while Lewis doth sit.

sp.speaker: Queen Margaret
sp.l: No, mighty King of France: now Margaret
Must strike her sail and learn awhile to serve
Where kings command. I was, I must confess,
Great Albion's queen in former golden days:
But now mischance hath trod my title down,
And with dishonour laid me on the ground;
Where I must take like seat unto my fortune,
And to my humble seat conform myself.

sp.speaker: Lewis XI
sp.l: Why, say, fair queen, whence springs this deep despair?

sp.speaker: Queen Margaret
sp.l: From such a cause as fills mine eyes with tears
And stops my tongue, while heart is drowned in cares.

sp.speaker: Lewis XI
sp.l: What e'er it be, be thou still like thyself,
And sit thee by our side: Seats her by him yield not thy neck
To fortune's yoke, but let thy dauntless mind
Still ride in triumph over all mischance.
Be plain, Queen Margaret, and tell thy grief;
It shall be eased, if France can yield relief.

sp.speaker: Queen Margaret
sp.l: Those gracious words revive my drooping thoughts
And give my tongue-tied sorrows leave to speak.
Now, therefore, be it known to noble Lewis,
That Henry, sole possessor of my love,
Is of a king become a banished man,
And forced to live in Scotland a forlorn;
While proud ambitious Edward Duke of York
Usurps the regal title and the seat
Of England's true-anointed lawful king.
This is the cause that I, poor Margaret,
With this my son, Prince Edward, Henry's heir,
Am come to crave thy just and lawful aid;
And if thou fail us, all our hope is done:
Scotland hath will to help, but cannot help;
Our people and our peers are both misled,
Our treasure seized, our soldiers put to flight,
And, as thou seest, ourselves in heavy plight.

sp.speaker: Lewis XI
sp.l: Renowned queen, with patience calm the storm,
While we bethink a means to break it off.

sp.speaker: Queen Margaret
sp.l: The more we stay, the stronger grows our foe.

sp.speaker: Lewis XI
sp.l: The more I stay, the more I'll succour thee.

sp.speaker: Queen Margaret
sp.l: O, but impatience waiteth on true sorrow.
And see where comes the breeder of my sorrow! Enter WARWICK.

sp.speaker: Lewis XI
sp.l: What's he approacheth boldly to our presence?

sp.speaker: Queen Margaret
sp.l: Our Earl of Warwick, Edward's greatest friend.

sp.speaker: Lewis XI
sp.l: Welcome, brave Warwick! What brings thee to France? He descends. She ariseth.

sp.speaker: Queen Margaret
sp.l: Ay, now begins a second storm to rise;
For this is he that moves both wind and tide.

sp.speaker: Warwick
sp.l: From worthy Edward, King of Albion,
My lord and sovereign, and thy vowed friend,
I come, in kindness and unfeigned love,
First, to do greetings to thy royal person;
And then to crave a league of amity;
And lastly, to confirm that amity
With nuptial knot, if thou vouchsafe to grant
That virtuous Lady Bona, thy fair sister,
To England's king in lawful marriage.

sp.speaker: Queen Margaret
sp.l: If that go forward, Henry's hope is done.

sp.speaker: Warwick
sp.l: And, gracious madam, in our king's behalf,
I am commanded, with your leave and favour,
Humbly to kiss your hand and with my tongue
To tell the passion of my sovereign's heart;
Where fame, late entering at his heedful ears,
Hath placed thy beauty's image and thy virtue.

sp.speaker: Queen Margaret
sp.l: King Lewis and Lady Bona, hear me speak,
Before you answer Warwick. His demand
Springs not from Edward's well-meant honest love,
But from deceit bred by necessity;
For how can tyrants safely govern home,
Unless abroad they purchase great alliance?
To prove him tyrant this reason may suffice,
That Henry liveth still; but were he dead,
Yet here Prince Edward stands, King Henry's son.
Look, therefore, Lewis, that by this league and marriage
Thou draw not on thy danger and dishonour;
For though usurpers sway the rule awhile,
Yet heavens are just, and time suppresseth wrongs.

sp.speaker: Warwick
sp.l: Injurious Margaret!

sp.speaker: Edward
sp.l: And why not queen?

sp.speaker: Warwick
sp.l: Because thy father Henry did usurp;
And thou no more art prince than she is queen.

sp.speaker: Oxford
sp.l: Then Warwick disannuls great John of Gaunt,
Which did subdue the greatest part of Spain;
And, after John of Gaunt, Henry the Fourth,
Whose wisdom was a mirror to the wisest;
And, after that wise prince, Henry the Fifth,
Who by his prowess conquered all France:
From these our Henry lineally descends.

sp.speaker: Warwick
sp.l: Oxford, how haps it, in this smooth discourse,
You told not how Henry the Sixth hath lost
All that which Henry the Fifth had gotten?
Methinks these peers of France should smile at that.
But for the rest, you tell a pedigree
Of threescore and two years; a silly time
To make prescription for a kingdom's worth.

sp.speaker: Oxford
sp.l: Why, Warwick canst thou speak against thy liege,
Whom thou obeyed'st thirty and six years,
And not bewray thy treason with a blush?

sp.speaker: Warwick
sp.l: Can Oxford, that did ever fence the right,
Now buckler falsehood with a pedigree?
For shame! leave Henry, and call Edward king.

sp.speaker: Oxford
sp.l: Call him my king by whose injurious doom
My elder brother, the Lord Aubrey Vere,
Was done to death? and more than so, my father
Even in the downfall of his mellowed years,
When nature brought him to the door of death?
No, Warwick, no; while life upholds this arm,
This arm upholds the house of Lancaster.

sp.speaker: Warwick
sp.l: And I the house of York.

sp.speaker: Lewis XI
sp.l: Queen Margaret, Prince Edward, and Oxford,
Vouchsafe at our request, to stand aside,
While I use further conference with Warwick. They stand aloof.

sp.speaker: Queen Margaret
sp.l: Heavens grant that Warwick's words bewitch him not!

sp.speaker: Lewis XI
sp.l: Now, Warwick, tell me, even upon thy conscience,
Is Edward your true king? for I were loath
To link with him that were not lawful chosen.

sp.speaker: Warwick
sp.l: Thereon I pawn my credit and mine honour.

sp.speaker: Lewis XI
sp.l: But is he gracious in the people's eye?

sp.speaker: Warwick
sp.l: The more that Henry was unfortunate.

sp.speaker: Lewis XI
sp.l: Then further, all dissembling set aside,
Tell me for truth the measure of his love
Unto our sister Bona

sp.speaker: Warwick
sp.l: Such it seems
As may beseem a monarch like himself.
Myself have often heard him say and swear
That this his love was an eternal plant,
Whereof the root was fixed in virtue's ground,
The leaves and fruit maintained with beauty's sun,
Exempt from envy, but not from disdain,
Unless the Lady Bona quit his pain.

sp.speaker: Lewis XI
sp.l: Now, sister, let us hear your firm resolve.

sp.speaker: Bona
sp.l: Your grant, or your denial, shall be mine: To War.
Yet I confess that often ere this day,
When I have heard your king's desert recounted,
Mine ear hath tempted judgement to desire.

sp.speaker: Lewis XI
sp.l: Then, Warwick, thus: our sister shall be Edward's;
And now forthwith shall articles be drawn
Touching the jointure that your king must make,
Which with her dowry shall be counterpoised.
Draw near, Queen Margaret, and be a witness
That Bona shall be wife to the English king.

sp.speaker: Edward
sp.l: To Edward, but not to the English king.

sp.speaker: Queen Margaret
sp.l: Deceitful Warwick! it was thy device
By this alliance to make void my suit:
Before thy coming Lewis was Henry's friend.

sp.speaker: Lewis XI
sp.l: And still is friend to him and Margaret:
But if your title to the crown be weak,
As may appear by Edward's good success,
Then 'tis but reason that I be released
From giving aid which late I promised.
Yet shall you have all kindness at my hand
That your estate requires and mine can yield.

sp.speaker: Warwick
sp.l: Henry now lives in Scotland at his ease,
Where having nothing, nothing can he lose.
And as for you yourself, our quondam queen,
You have a father able to maintain you;
And better 'twere you troubled him than France.

sp.speaker: Queen Margaret
sp.l: Peace, impudent and shameless Warwick,
Proud setter-up and puller-down of kings!
I will not hence, till, with my talk and tears,
Both full of truth, I make King Lewis behold
Thy sly conveyance and thy lord's false love;
For both of you are birds of selfsame feather. Post blows a horn within.

sp.speaker: Lewis XI
sp.l: Warwick, this is some post to us or thee. Enter a Post.

sp.speaker: Post
sp.l: My lord ambassador, these letters are for you,
Sent from your brother, Marquess Montague: To Lewis
These from our king unto your majesty: To Margaret
And, madam, these for you; from whom I know not. They all read their letters.

sp.speaker: Oxford
sp.l: I like it well that our fair queen and mistress
Smiles at her news, while Warwick frowns at his.

sp.speaker: Edward
sp.l: Nay, mark how Lewis stamps, as he were nettled:
I hope all's for the best.

sp.speaker: Lewis XI
sp.l: Warwick, what are thy news? and yours, fair queen?

sp.speaker: Queen Margaret
sp.l: Mine, such as fill my heart with unhoped joys.

sp.speaker: Warwick
sp.l: Mine, full of sorrow and heart's discontent.

sp.speaker: Lewis XI
sp.l: What! has your king married the Lady Grey?
And now, to soothe your forgery and his,
Sends me a paper to persuade me patience?
Is this the alliance that he seeks with France?
Dare he presume to scorn us in this manner?

sp.speaker: Queen Margaret
sp.l: I told your majesty as much before:
This proveth Edward's love and Warwick's honesty.

sp.speaker: Warwick
sp.l: King Lewis, I here protest, in sight of heaven,
And by the hope I have of heavenly bliss,
That I am clear from this misdeed of Edward's,
No more my king, for he dishonours me,
But most himself, if he could see his shame.
Did I forget that by the house of York
My father came untimely to his death?
Did I let pass the abuse done to my niece?
Did I impale him with the regal crown?
Did I put Henry from his native right?
And am I guerdoned at the last with shame?
Shame on himself, for my desert is honour:
And to repair my honour lost for him,
I here renounce him and return to Henry.
My noble queen, let former grudges pass,
And henceforth I am thy true servitor:
I will revenge his wrong to Lady Bona
And replant Henry in his former state.

sp.speaker: Queen Margaret
sp.l: Warwick, these words have turned my hate to love;
And I forgive and quite forget old faults,
And joy that thou becomest King Henry's friend.

sp.speaker: Warwick
sp.l: So much his friend, ay, his unfeigned friend,
That, if King Lewis vouchsafe to furnish us
With some few bands of chosen soldiers,
I'll undertake to land them on our coast
And force the tyrant from his seat by war.
'Tis not his new-made bride shall succour him
And as for Clarence, as my letters tell me,
He's very likely now to fall from him,
For matching more for wanton lust than honour,
Or than for strength and safety of our country.

sp.speaker: Bona
sp.l: Dear brother, how shall Bona be revenged
But by thy help to this distressed queen?

sp.speaker: Queen Margaret
sp.l: Renowned prince, how shall poor Henry live,
Unless thou rescue him from foul despair?

sp.speaker: Bona
sp.l: My quarrel and this English queen's are one.

sp.speaker: Warwick
sp.l: And mine, fair lady Bona, joins with yours.

sp.speaker: Lewis XI
sp.l: And mine with hers, and thine, and Margaret's.
Therefore at last I firmly am resolved
You shall have aid.

sp.speaker: Queen Margaret
sp.l: Let me give humble thanks for all at once.

sp.speaker: Lewis XI
sp.l: Then, England's messenger, return in post,
And tell false Edward, thy supposed king,
That Lewis of France is sending over masquers
To revel it with him and his new bride:
Thou seest what's past, go fear thy king withal.

sp.speaker: Bona
sp.l: Tell him, in hope he'll prove a widower shortly,
I wear the willow garland for his sake.

sp.speaker: Queen Margaret
sp.l: Tell him, my mourning weeds are laid aside,
And I am ready to put armour on.

sp.speaker: Warwick
sp.l: Tell him from me that he hath done me wrong,
And therefore I'll uncrown him ere't be long.
There's thy reward: be gone. Exit Post.

sp.speaker: Lewis XI
sp.l: But, Warwick,
Thou and Oxford, with five thousand men,
Shall cross the seas, and bid false Edward battle;
And as occasion serves, this noble queen
And prince shall follow with a fresh supply.
Yet, ere thou go, but answer me one doubt,
What pledge have we of thy firm loyalty?

sp.speaker: Warwick
sp.l: This shall assure my constant loyalty,
That if our queen and this young prince agree,
I'll join mine eldest daughter and my joy
To him forthwith in holy wedlock bands.

sp.speaker: Queen Margaret
sp.l: Yes, I agree, and thank you for your motion.
Son Edward, she is fair and virtuous,
Therefore delay not, give thy hand to Warwick;
And with thy hand, thy faith irrevocable,
That only Warwick's daughter shall be thine.

sp.speaker: Edward
sp.l: Yes, I accept her, for she well deserves it;
And here, to pledge my vow, I give my hand. He gives his hand to Warwick.

sp.speaker: Lewis XI
sp.l: Why stay we now? These soldiers shall be levied,
And thou, Lord Bourbon, our high admiral,
Shall waft them over with our royal fleet.
I long till Edward fall by war's mischance,
For mocking marriage with a dame of France. Exeunt all but Warwick.

sp.speaker: Warwick
sp.l: I came from Edward as ambassador,
But I return his sworn and mortal foe:
Matter of marriage was the charge he gave me,
But dreadful war shall answer his demand.
Had he none else to make a stale but me?
Then none but I shall turn his jest to sorrow.
I was the chief that raised him to the crown,
And I'll be chief to bring him down again:
Not that I pity Henry's misery,
But seek revenge on Edward's mockery. Exit.

div.head: Act 4, Scene 1
div.stage: Enter GLOUCESTER, CLARENCE, SOMERSET, and MONTAGUE.

sp.speaker: Gloucester
sp.l: Now tell me, brother Clarence, what think you
Of this new marriage with the Lady Grey?
Hath not our brother made a worthy choice?

sp.speaker: Clarence
sp.l: Alas, you know, 'tis far from hence to France;
How could he stay till Warwick made return?

sp.speaker: Somerset
sp.l: My lords, forbear this talk; here comes the king.

sp.speaker: Gloucester
sp.l: And his well-chosen bride.

sp.speaker: Clarence
sp.l: I mind to tell him plainly what I think. Flourish. Enter KING EDWARD, attended; LADY GREY, as Queen; PEMBROKE, STAFFORD, HASTINGS, and others.

sp.speaker: King Edward
sp.l: Now, brother of Clarence, how like you our choice,
That you stand pensive, as half malcontent?

sp.speaker: Clarence
sp.l: As well as Lewis of France, or the Earl of Warwick,
Which are so weak of courage and in judgement
That they'll take no offence at our abuse.

sp.speaker: King Edward
sp.l: Suppose they take offence without a cause,
They are but Lewis and Warwick: I am Edward,
Your king and Warwick's, and must have my will.

sp.speaker: Gloucester
sp.l: And shall have your will, because our king:
Yet hasty marriage seldom proveth well.

sp.speaker: King Edward
sp.l: Yea, brother Richard, are you offended too?

sp.speaker: Gloucester
sp.l: Not I:
No, God forbid that I should wish them severed
Whom God hath joined together; ay, and 'twere pity
To sunder them that yoke so well together.

sp.speaker: King Edward
sp.l: Setting your scorns and your mislike aside,
Tell me some reason why the Lady Grey
Should not become my wife and England's queen.
And you too, Somerset and Montague,
Speak freely what you think.

sp.speaker: Clarence
sp.l: Then this is mine opinion: that King Lewis
Becomes your enemy for mocking him
About the marriage of the Lady Bona

sp.speaker: Gloucester
sp.l: And Warwick, doing what you gave in charge,
Is now dishonoured by this new marriage.

sp.speaker: King Edward
sp.l: What if both Lewis and Warwick be appeased
By such invention as I can devise?

sp.speaker: Montague
sp.l: Yet, to have joined with France in such alliance
Would more have strengthened this our commonwealth
'Gainst foreign storms than any home-bred marriage.

sp.speaker: Hastings
sp.l: Why, knows not Montague that of itself
England is safe, if true within itself?

sp.speaker: Montague
sp.l: But the safer when 'tis backed with France.

sp.speaker: Hastings
sp.l: 'Tis better using France than trusting France:
Let us be backed with God and with the seas
Which He hath given for fence impregnable,
And with their helps only defend ourselves;
In them and in ourselves our safety lies.

sp.speaker: Clarence
sp.l: For this one speech Lord Hastings well deserves
To have the heir of the Lord Hungerford.

sp.speaker: King Edward
sp.l: Ay, what of that? it was my will and grant;
And for this once my will shall stand for law.

sp.speaker: Gloucester
sp.l: And yet methinks your grace hath not done well,
To give the heir and daughter of Lord Scales
Unto the brother of your loving bride;
She better would have fitted me or Clarence:
But in your bride you bury brotherhood.

sp.speaker: Clarence
sp.l: Or else you would not have bestowed the heir
Of the Lord Bonville on your new wife's son,
And leave your brothers to go speed elsewhere.

sp.speaker: King Edward
sp.l: Alas, poor Clarence! is it for a wife
That thou art malcontent? I will provide thee.

sp.speaker: Clarence
sp.l: In choosing for yourself, you showed your judgement,
Which being shallow, you shall give me leave
To play the broker in mine own behalf;
And to that end I shortly mind to leave you.

sp.speaker: King Edward
sp.l: Leave me, or tarry, Edward will be king,
And not be tied unto his brother's will.

sp.speaker: Queen Elizabeth
sp.l: My lords, before it pleased his majesty
To raise my state to title of a queen,
Do me but right, and you must all confess
That I was not ignoble of descent;
And meaner than myself have had like fortune.
But as this title honours me and mine,
So your dislikes, to whom I would be pleasing,
Doth cloud my joys with danger and with sorrow.

sp.speaker: King Edward
sp.l: My love, forbear to fawn upon their frowns:
What danger or what sorrow can befall thee,
So long as Edward is thy constant friend,
And their true sovereign, whom they must obey?
Nay, whom they shall obey, and love thee too,
Unless they seek for hatred at my hands;
Which if they do, yet will I keep thee safe,
And they shall feel the vengeance of my wrath.

sp.speaker: Gloucester
sp.l: I hear, yet say not much, but think the more. Aside. Enter a Post.

sp.speaker: King Edward
sp.l: Now, messenger, what letters or what news
From France?

sp.speaker: Post
sp.l: My sovereign liege, no letters; and few words,
But such as I, without your special pardon,
Dare not relate.

sp.speaker: King Edward
sp.l: Go to, we pardon thee: therefore, in brief
Tell me their words as near as thou canst guess them.
What answer makes King Lewis unto our letters?

sp.speaker: Post
sp.l: At my depart, these were his very words:
“Go tell false Edward, the supposed king,
That Lewis of France is sending over masquers
To revel it with him and his new bride.”

sp.speaker: King Edward
sp.l: Is Lewis so brave? belike he thinks me Henry.
But what said Lady Bona to my marriage?

sp.speaker: Post
sp.l: These were her words, uttered with mild disdain:
“Tell him, in hope he'll prove a widower shortly,
I'll wear the willow garland for his sake.”

sp.speaker: King Edward
sp.l: I blame not her, she could say little less;
She had the wrong. But what said Henry's queen?
For I have heard that she was there in place.

sp.speaker: Post
sp.l: “Tell him,” quoth she, “my mourning weeds are done,
And I am ready to put armour on.”

sp.speaker: King Edward
sp.l: Belike she minds to play the Amazon.
But what said Warwick to these injuries?

sp.speaker: Post
sp.l: He more incensed against your majesty
Than all the rest, discharged me with these words:
“Tell him from me that he hath done me wrong,
And therefore I'll uncrown him ere't be long.”

sp.speaker: King Edward
sp.l: Ha! durst the traitor breathe out so proud words?
Well, I will arm me, being thus forewarned:
They shall have wars and pay for their presumption.
But say, is Warwick friends with Margaret?

sp.speaker: Post
sp.l: Ay, gracious sovereign; they are so linked in friendship,
That young Prince Edward marries Warwick's daughter.

sp.speaker: Clarence
sp.l: Belike the elder; Clarence will have the younger.
Now, brother king, farewell, and sit you fast,
For I will hence to Warwick's other daughter;
That, though I want a kingdom, yet in marriage
I may not prove inferior to yourself.
You that love me and Warwick, follow me. Exit Clarence, and Somerset follows.

sp.speaker: Gloucester
sp.l: Not I:
My thoughts aim at a further matter; I
Stay not for the love of Edward, but the crown.

sp.speaker: King Edward
sp.l: Clarence and Somerset both gone to Warwick!
Yet am I armed against the worst can happen;
And haste is needful in this desperate case.
Pembroke and Stafford, you in our behalf
Go levy men, and make prepare for war;
They are already, or quickly will be landed:
Myself in person will straight follow you. Exeunt Pembroke and Stafford.
But, ere I go, Hastings and Montague,
Resolve my doubt. You twain, of all the rest.
Are near to Warwick by blood and by alliance:
Tell me if you love Warwick more than me?
If it be so, then both depart to him;
I rather wish you foes than hollow friends:
But if you mind to hold your true obedience,
Give me assurance with some friendly vow,
That I may never have you in suspect.

sp.speaker: Montague
sp.l: So God help Montague as he proves true.

sp.speaker: Hastings
sp.l: And Hastings as he favours Edward's cause!

sp.speaker: King Edward
sp.l: Now, brother Richard, will you stand by us?

sp.speaker: Gloucester
sp.l: Ay, in despite of all that shall withstand you.

sp.speaker: King Edward
sp.l: Why, so! then am I sure of victory.
Now therefore let us hence; and lose no hour,
Till we meet Warwick with his foreign power. Exeunt.

div.head: Act 4, Scene 2
div.stage: Enter WARWICK and OXFORD, with French soldiers.

sp.speaker: Warwick
sp.l: Trust me, my lord, all hitherto goes well;
The common people by numbers swarm to us. Enter CLARENCE and SOMERSET.
But see where Somerset and Clarence comes!
Speak suddenly, my lords, are we all friends?

sp.speaker: Clarence
sp.l: Fear not that, my lord.

sp.speaker: Warwick
sp.l: Then, gentle Clarence, welcome unto Warwick;
And welcome, Somerset: I hold it cowardice
To rest mistrustful where a noble heart
Hath pawned an open hand in sign of love;
Else might I think that Clarence, Edward's brother,
Were but a feigned friend to our proceedings:
But welcome, sweet Clarence; my daughter shall be thine.
And now what rests but, in night's coverture,
Thy brother being carelessly encamped,
His soldiers lurking in the town about,
And but attended by a simple guard,
We may surprise and take him at our pleasure?
Our scouts have found the adventure very easy:
That as Ulysses and stout Diomede
With sleight and manhood stole to Rhesus' tents,
And brought from thence the Thracian fatal steeds,
So we, well covered with the night's black mantle,
At unawares may beat down Edward's guard
And seize himself; I say not, slaughter him,
For I intend but only to surprise him.
You that will follow me to this attempt,
Applaud the name of Henry with your leader. They all cry, “Henry!”
Why, then, let's on our way in silent sort:
For Warwick and his friends, God and Saint George! Exeunt.

div.head: Act 4, Scene 3
div.stage: Enter three Watchmen, to guard the KING'S tent.

sp.speaker: First Watchman
sp.l: Come on, my masters, each man take his stand:
The king by this is set him down to sleep.

sp.speaker: Second Watchman
sp.l: What, will he not to bed?

sp.speaker: First Watchman
sp.l: Why, no; for he hath made a solemn vow
Never to lie and take his natural rest
Till Warwick or himself be quite suppressed.

sp.speaker: Second Watchman
sp.l: To-morrow then belike shall be the day,
If Warwick be so near as men report.

sp.speaker: Third Watchman
sp.l: But say, I pray, what nobleman is that
That with the king here resteth in his tent?

sp.speaker: First Watchman
sp.l: 'Tis the Lord Hastings, the king's chiefest friend.

sp.speaker: Third Watchman
sp.l: O, is it so? But why commands the king
That his chief followers lodge in towns about him,
While he himself keeps in the cold field?

sp.speaker: Second Watchman
sp.l: 'Tis the more honour, because more dangerous.

sp.speaker: Third Watchman
sp.l: Ay, but give me worship and quietness;
I like it better than a dangerous honour.
If Warwick knew in what estate he stands,
'Tis to be doubted he would waken him.

sp.speaker: First Watchman
sp.l: Unless our halberds did shut up his passage.

sp.speaker: Second Watchman
sp.l: Ay, wherefore else guard we his royal tent,
But to defend his person from night-foes? Enter WARWICK, CLARENCE, OXFORD, SOMERSET, and French soldiers, silent all.

sp.speaker: Warwick
sp.l: This is his tent; and see where stand his guard.
Courage, my masters! honour now or never!
But follow me, and Edward shall be ours.

sp.speaker: First Watchman
sp.l: Who goes there?

sp.speaker: Second Watchman
sp.l: Stay, or thou diest! Warwick and the rest cry all, “Warwick! Warwick!” and set upon the Guard, who fly, crying, “Arm! arm!” Warwick and the rest following. them. The drum playing and trumpet sounding, re-enter WARWICK, SOMERSET, and the rest, bringing the KING out in his gown, sitting in a chair. RICHARD and HASTINGS fly over the stage.

sp.speaker: Somerset
sp.l: What are they that fly there?

sp.speaker: Warwick
sp.l: Richard and Hastings: let them go; here is
The duke.

sp.speaker: King Edward
sp.l: The duke! Why, Warwick, when we parted,
Thou calledst me king.

sp.speaker: Warwick
sp.l: Ay, but the case is altered:
When you disgraced me in my embassade,
Then I degraded you from being king,
And come now to create you Duke of York.
Alas! how should you govern any kingdom,
That know not how to use ambassadors,
Nor how to be contented with one wife,
Nor how to use your brothers brotherly,
Nor how to study for the people's welfare,
Nor how to shroud yourself from enemies?

sp.speaker: King Edward
sp.l: Yea, brother of Clarence, art thou here too?
Nay, then I see that Edward needs must down.
Yet, Warwick, in despite of all mischance,
Of thee thyself and all thy complices,
Edward will always bear himself as king:
Though fortune's malice overthrow my state,
My mind exceeds the compass of her wheel.

sp.speaker: Warwick
sp.l: Then, for his mind, be Edward England's king: Takes off his crown.
But Henry now shall wear the English crown,
And be true king indeed, thou but the shadow.
My Lord of Somerset, at my request,
See that forthwith Duke Edward be conveyed
Unto my brother, Archbishop of York.
When I have fought with Pembroke and his fellows,
I'll follow you, and tell what answer
Lewis and the Lady Bona send to him.
Now, for awhile farewell, good Duke of York. They lead him out forcibly.

sp.speaker: King Edward
sp.l: What fates impose, that men must needs abide;
It boots not to resist both wind and tide. Exit, guarded.

sp.speaker: Oxford
sp.l: What now remains, my lords, for us to do
But march to London with our soldiers?

sp.speaker: Warwick
sp.l: Ay, that's the first thing that we have to do;
To free King Henry from imprisonment
And see him seated in the regal throne. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Rivers
sp.l: Madam, what makes you in this sudden change?

sp.speaker: Queen Elizabeth
sp.l: Why, brother Rivers, are you yet to learn
What late misfortune is befallen King Edward?

sp.speaker: Rivers
sp.l: What! loss of some pitched battle against Warwick?

sp.speaker: Queen Elizabeth
sp.l: No, but the loss of his own royal person.

sp.speaker: Rivers
sp.l: Then is my sovereign slain?

sp.speaker: Queen Elizabeth
sp.l: Ay, almost slain, for he is taken prisoner,
Either betrayed by falsehood of his guard
Or by his foe surprised at unawares:
And, as I further have to understand,
Is new committed to the Bishop of York,
Fell Warwick's brother and by that our foe.

sp.speaker: Rivers
sp.l: These news I must confess are full of grief;
Yet, gracious madam, bear it as you may:
Warwick may lose, that now hath won the day.

sp.speaker: Queen Elizabeth
sp.l: Till then fair hope must hinder life's decay.
And I the rather wean me from despair
For love of Edward's offspring in my womb:
This is it that makes me bridle passion
And bear with mildness my misfortune's cross;
Ay, ay, for this I draw in many a tear
And stop the rising of blood-sucking sighs,
Lest with my sighs or tears I blast or drown
King Edward's fruit, true heir to the English crown.

sp.speaker: Rivers
sp.l: But, madam, where is Warwick then become?

sp.speaker: Queen Elizabeth
sp.l: I am informed that he comes toward London,
To set the crown once more on Henry's head:
Guess thou the rest; King Edward's friends must down,
But, to prevent the tyrant's violence, —
For trust not him that hath once broken faith, —
I'll hence forthwith unto the sanctuary,
To save at least the heir of Edward's right:
There shall I rest secure from force and fraud.
Come, therefore, let us fly while we may fly:
If Warwick take us we are sure to die. Exeunt.

div.head: Act 4, Scene 5
div.stage: A park near Middleham Castle in Yorkshire.
Enter GLOUCESTER, LORD HASTINGS, and SIR WILLIAM STANLEY.

sp.speaker: Gloucester
sp.l: Now, my Lord Hastings and Sir William Stanley,
Leave off to wonder why I drew you hither,
Into this chiefest thicket of the park.
Thus stands the case: you know our king, my brother,
Is prisoner to the bishop here, at whose hands
He hath good usage and great liberty,
And, often but attended with weak guard,
Comes hunting this way to disport himself.
I have advertised him by secret means
That if about this hour he make this way
Under the colour of his usual game.
He shall here find his friends with horse and men
To set him free from his captivity. Enter KING EDWARD and a Huntsman with him.

sp.speaker: Huntsman
sp.l: This way, my lord; for this way lies the game.

sp.speaker: King Edward
sp.l: Nay, this way, man: see where the huntsmen stand.
Now, brother of Gloucester, Lord Hastings, and the rest,
Stand you thus close, to steal the bishop's deer?

sp.speaker: Gloucester
sp.l: Brother, the time and case requireth haste:
Your horse stands ready at the park-corner.

sp.speaker: King Edward
sp.l: But whither shall we then?

sp.speaker: Hastings
sp.l: To Lynn, my lord,
And shipped from thence to Flanders.

sp.speaker: Gloucester
sp.l: Well guessed, believe me; for that was my meaning.

sp.speaker: King Edward
sp.l: Stanley, I will requite thy forwardness.

sp.speaker: Gloucester
sp.l: But wherefore stay we? 'tis no time to talk.

sp.speaker: King Edward
sp.l: Huntsman, what say'st thou? wilt thou go along?

sp.speaker: Huntsman
sp.l: Better do so than tarry and be hanged.

sp.speaker: Gloucester
sp.l: Come then, away; let's ha' no more ado.

sp.speaker: King Edward
sp.l: Bishop, farewell: shield thee from Warwick's frown;
And pray that I may repossess the crown. Exeunt.

div.head: Act 4, Scene 6
div.stage: Flourish. Enter KING HENRY, CLARENCE, WARWICK, SOMERSET, young RICHMOND, OXFORD, MONTAGUE, and Lieutenant of the Tower.

sp.speaker: King Henry
sp.l: Master lieutenant, now that God and friends
Have shaken Edward from the regal seat,
And turned my captive state to liberty,
My fear to hope, my sorrows unto joys,
At our enlargement what are thy due fees?

sp.speaker: Lieutenant
sp.l: Subjects may challenge nothing of their sovereigns;
But if an humble prayer may prevail,
I then crave pardon of your majesty.

sp.speaker: King Henry
sp.l: For what, lieutenant? for well using me?
Nay, be thou sure I'll well requite thy kindness,
For that it made my imprisonment a pleasure;
Ay, such a pleasure as incaged birds
Conceive when after many moody thoughts
At last by notes of household harmony
They quite forget their loss of liberty.
But, Warwick, after God, thou set'st me free,
And chiefly therefore I thank God and thee;
He was the author, thou the instrument.
Therefore, that I may conquer fortune's spite
By living low, where fortune cannot hurt me,
And that the people of this blessed land
May not be punished with my thwarting stars,
Warwick, although my head still wear the crown,
I here resign my government to thee,
For thou art fortunate in all thy deeds.

sp.speaker: Warwick
sp.l: Your grace hath still been famed for virtuous;
And now may seem as wise as virtuous,
By spying and avoiding fortune's malice,
For few men rightly temper with the stars:
Yet in this one thing let me blame your grace,
For choosing me when Clarence is in place.

sp.speaker: Clarence
sp.l: No, Warwick, thou art worthy of the sway,
To whom the heavens in thy nativity
Adjudged an olive branch and laurel crown,
As likely to be blest in peace and war;
And therefore I yield thee my free consent.

sp.speaker: Warwick
sp.l: And I choose Clarence only for protector.

sp.speaker: King Henry
sp.l: Warwick and Clarence, give me both your hands:
Now join your hands, and with your hands your hearts,
That no dissension hinder government:
I make you both protectors of this land,
While I myself will lead a private life
And in devotion spend my latter days,
To sin's rebuke and my Creator's praise.

sp.speaker: Warwick
sp.l: What answers Clarence to his sovereign's will?

sp.speaker: Clarence
sp.l: That he consents, if Warwick yield consent;
For on thy fortune I repose myself.

sp.speaker: Warwick
sp.l: Why, then, though loath, yet must I be content:
We'll yoke together, like a double shadow
To Henry's body, and supply his place;
I mean, in bearing weight of government,
While he enjoys the honour and his ease.
And, Clarence, now then it is more than needful
Forthwith that Edward be pronounced a traitor,
And all his lands and goods confiscate.

sp.speaker: Clarence
sp.l: What else? and that succession be determined.

sp.speaker: Warwick
sp.l: Ay, therein Clarence shall not want his part.

sp.speaker: King Henry
sp.l: But, with the first of all your chief affairs,
Let me entreat, for I command no more,
That Margaret your queen and my son Edward
Be sent for, to return from France with speed;
For, till I see them here, by doubtful fear
My joy of liberty is half eclipsed.

sp.speaker: Clarence
sp.l: It shall be done, my sovereign, with all speed.

sp.speaker: King Henry
sp.l: My Lord of Somerset, what youth is that,
Of whom you seem to have so tender care?

sp.speaker: Somerset
sp.l: My liege, it is young Henry, earl of Richmond.

sp.speaker: King Henry
sp.l: Come hither, England's hope. Lays his hand on his head
If secret powers
Suggest but truth to my divining thoughts,
This pretty lad will prove our country's bliss.
His looks are full of peaceful majesty,
His head by nature framed to wear a crown,
His hand to wield a sceptre, and himself
Likely in time to bless a regal throne.
Make much of him, my lords, for this is he
Must help you more than you are hurt by me. Enter a Post.

sp.speaker: Warwick
sp.l: What news, my friend?

sp.speaker: Post
sp.l: That Edward is escaped from your brother,
And fled, as he hears since, to Burgundy.

sp.speaker: Warwick
sp.l: Unsavoury news! but how made he escape?

sp.speaker: Post
sp.l: He was conveyed by Richard Duke of Gloucester
And the Lord Hastings, who attended him
In secret ambush on the forest side
And from the bishop's huntsmen rescued him;
For hunting was his daily exercise.

sp.speaker: Warwick
sp.l: My brother was too careless of his charge.
But let us hence, my sovereign, to provide
A salve for any sore that may betide. Exeunt all but Somerset, Richmond, and Oxford.

sp.speaker: Somerset
sp.l: My lord, I like not of this flight of Edward's;
For doubtless Burgundy will yield him help,
And we shall have more wars before't be long.
As Henry's late presaging prophecy
Did glad my heart with hope of this young Richmond,
So doth my heart misgive me, in these conflicts
What may befall him, to his harm and ours:
Therefore, Lord Oxford, to prevent the worst,
Forthwith we'll send him hence to Brittany,
Till storms be past of civil enmity.

sp.speaker: Oxford
sp.l: Ay, for if Edward repossess the crown,
'Tis like that Richmond with the rest shall down.

sp.speaker: Somerset
sp.l: It shall be so; he shall to Brittany.
Come, therefore, let's about it speedily. Exeunt.

div.head: Act 4, Scene 7
div.stage: Flourish. Enter KING EDWARD, GLOUCESTER, HASTINGS, and Soldiers.

sp.speaker: King Edward
sp.l: Now, brother Richard, Lord Hastings, and the rest,
Yet thus far fortune maketh us amends,
And says that once more I shall interchange
My waned state for Henry's regal crown.
Well have we passed and now repassed the seas
And brought desired help from Burgundy:
What then remains, we being thus arrived
From Ravenspurgh haven before the gates of York,
But that we enter, as into our dukedom?

sp.speaker: Gloucester
sp.l: The gates made fast! Brother, I like not this;
For many men that stumble at the threshold
Are well foretold that danger lurks within.

sp.speaker: King Edward
sp.l: Tush, man, abodements must not now affright us:
By fair or foul means we must enter in,
For hither will our friends repair to us.

sp.speaker: Hastings
sp.l: My liege, I'll knock once more to summon them. Enter, on the walls, the Mayor of York, and his brethren.

sp.speaker: Mayor
sp.l: My lords, we were forewarned of your coming,
And shut the gates for safety of ourselves;
For now we owe allegiance unto Henry.

sp.speaker: King Edward
sp.l: But, master mayor, if Henry be your king,
Yet Edward at the least is Duke of York.

sp.speaker: Mayor
sp.l: True, my good lord; I know you for no less.

sp.speaker: King Edward
sp.l: Why, and I challenge nothing but my dukedom,
As being well content with that alone.

sp.speaker: Gloucester
sp.l: But when the fox hath once got in his nose,
He'll soon find means to make the body follow.

sp.speaker: Hastings
sp.l: Why, master mayor, why stand you in a doubt?
Open the gates; we are King Henry's friends.

sp.speaker: Mayor
sp.l: Ay, say you so? the gates shall then be opened. They descend.

sp.speaker: Gloucester
sp.l: A wise stout captain, and soon persuaded!

sp.speaker: Hastings
sp.l: The good old man would fain that all were well,
So 'twere not 'long of him; but being entered,
I doubt not, I, but we shall soon persuade
Both him and all his brothers unto reason. Enter the Mayor and two Aldermen, below.

sp.speaker: King Edward
sp.l: So, master mayor: these gates must not be shut
But in the night or in the time of war.
What! fear not, man, but yield me up the keys; Takes his keys.
For Edward will defend the town and thee,
And all those friends that deign to follow me. March. Enter MONTGOMERY, with drum and soldiers.

sp.speaker: Gloucester
sp.l: Brother, this is Sir John Montgomery,
Our trusty friend, unless I be deceived.

sp.speaker: King Edward
sp.l: Welcome, Sir John! But why come you in arms?

sp.speaker: Montague
sp.l: To help King Edward in his time of storm,
As every loyal subject ought to do.

sp.speaker: King Edward
sp.l: Thanks, good Montgomery; but we now forget
Our title to the crown and only claim
Our dukedom till God please to send the rest.

sp.speaker: Montague
sp.l: Then fare you well, for I will hence again:
I came to serve a king and not a duke.
Drummer, strike up, and let us march away. The drum begins to march.

sp.speaker: King Edward
sp.l: Nay, stay, Sir John, awhile, and we'll debate
By what safe means the crown may be recovered.

sp.speaker: Montague
sp.l: What talk you of debating? in few words,
If you'll not here proclaim yourself our king,
I'll leave you to your fortune and be gone
To keep them back that come to succour you:
Why shall we fight, if you pretend no title?

sp.speaker: Gloucester
sp.l: Why, brother, wherefore stand you on nice points?

sp.speaker: King Edward
sp.l: When we grow stronger, then we'll make our claim:
Till then, 'tis wisdom to conceal our meaning.

sp.speaker: Hastings
sp.l: Away with scrupulous wit! now arms must rule.

sp.speaker: Gloucester
sp.l: And fearless minds climb soonest unto crowns.
Brother, we will proclaim you out of hand;
The bruit thereof will bring you many friends.

sp.speaker: King Edward
sp.l: Then be it as you will; for 'tis my right,
And Henry but usurps the diadem.

sp.speaker: Montague
sp.l: Ay, now my sovereign speaketh like himself;
And now will I be Edward's champion.

sp.speaker: Hastings
sp.l: Sound trumpet; Edward shall be here proclaimed:
Come, fellow soldier, make thou proclamation. Flourish.

sp.speaker: Soldier
sp.ab: Edward the Fourth, by the grace of God, king of
England and France, and lord of Ireland, etc.

sp.speaker: Montague
sp.l: And whosoe'er gainsays King Edward's right,
By this I challenge him to single fight. Throws down his gauntlet.

sp.speaker: All
sp.l: Long live Edward the Fourth!

sp.speaker: King Edward
sp.l: Thanks, brave Montgomery; and thanks unto you all:
If fortune serve me, I'll requite this kindness.
Now, for this night, let's harbour here in York;
And when the morning sun shall raise his car
Above the border of this horizon,
We'll forward towards Warwick and his mates;
For well I wot that Henry is no soldier.
Ah, froward Clarence! how evil it beseems thee,
To flatter Henry and forsake thy brother!
Yet, as we may, we'll meet both thee and Warwick.
Come on, brave soldiers: doubt not of the day,
And, that once gotten, doubt not of large pay. Exeunt.

div.head: Act 4, Scene 8
div.stage: Flourish. Enter KING HENRY, WARWICK, MONTAGUE, CLARENCE, EXETER, and OXFORD.

sp.speaker: Warwick
sp.l: What counsel, lords? Edward from Belgia,
With hasty Germans and blunt Hollanders,
Hath passed in safety through the narrow seas,
And with his troops doth march amain to London;
And many giddy people flock to him.

sp.speaker: King Henry
sp.l: Let's levy men, and beat him back again.

sp.speaker: Clarence
sp.l: A little fire is quickly trodden out;
Which, being suffered, rivers cannot quench.

sp.speaker: Warwick
sp.l: In Warwickshire I have true-hearted friends,
Not mutinous in peace, yet bold in war;
Those will I muster up; and thou, son Clarence,
Shalt stir up in Suffolk, Norfolk and in Kent,
The knights and gentlemen to come with thee:
Thou, brother Montague, in Buckingham,
Northampton and in Leicestershire, shalt find
Men well inclined to hear what thou command'st:
And thou, brave Oxford, wondrous well beloved,
In Oxfordshire shalt muster up thy friends.
My sovereign, with the loving citizens,
Like to his island girt in with the ocean,
Or modest Dian circled with her nymphs,
Shall rest in London till we come to him.
Fair lords, take leave and stand not to reply.
Farewell, my sovereign.

sp.speaker: King Henry
sp.l: Farewell, my Hector, and my Troy's true hope.

sp.speaker: Clarence
sp.l: In sign of truth, I kiss your highness' hand.

sp.speaker: King Henry
sp.l: Well-minded Clarence, be thou fortunate!

sp.speaker: Montague
sp.l: Comfort, my lord; and so I take my leave.

sp.speaker: Oxford
sp.l: And thus I seal my truth, and bid adieu.

sp.speaker: King Henry
sp.l: Sweet Oxford, and my loving Montague,
And all at once, once more a happy farewell.

sp.speaker: Warwick
sp.l: Farewell, sweet lords: let's meet at Coventry. Exeunt all but King and Exeter.

sp.speaker: King Henry
sp.l: Here at the palace will I rest awhile.
Cousin of Exeter, what thinks your lordship?
Methinks the power that Edward hath in field
Should not be able to encounter mine.

sp.speaker: Exeter
sp.l: The doubt is that he will seduce the rest.

sp.speaker: King Henry
sp.l: That's not my fear; my meed hath got me fame:
I have not stopped mine ears to their demands,
Nor posted off their suits with slow delays;
My pity hath been balm to heal their wounds,
My mildness hath allayed their swelling griefs,
My mercy dried their water-flowing tears;
I have not been desirous of their wealth,
Nor much oppressed them with great subsidies,
Nor forward of revenge, though they much erred:
Then why should they love Edward more than me?
No, Exeter, these graces challenge grace:
And when the lion fawns upon the lamb,
The lamb will never cease to follow him. Shout within, “A Lancaster! A Lancaster!”

sp.speaker: Exeter
sp.l: Hark, hark, my lord! what shouts are these? Enter KING EDWARD, GLOUCESTER, and soldiers.

sp.speaker: King Edward
sp.l: Seize on the shame-faced Henry, bear him hence;
And once again proclaim us king of England.
You are the fount that makes small brooks to flow:
Now stops thy spring; my sea shall suck them dry,
And swell so much the higher by their ebb.
Hence with him to the Tower; let him not speak. Exeunt some with King Henry.
And, lords, towards Coventry bend we our course,
Where peremptory Warwick now remains:
The sun shines hot; and, if we use delay,
Cold biting winter mars our hoped-for hay.

sp.speaker: Gloucester
sp.l: Away betimes, before his forces join,
And take the great-grown traitor unawares:
Brave warriors, march amain towards Coventry. Exeunt.

div.head: Act 5, Scene 1
div.stage: Enter WARWICK, the Mayor of Coventry, two Messengers, and others upon the walls.

sp.speaker: Warwick
sp.l: Where is the post that came from valiant Oxford?
How far hence is thy lord, mine honest fellow?

sp.speaker: First Messenger
sp.l: By this at Dunsmore, marching hitherward.

sp.speaker: Warwick
sp.l: How far off is our brother Montague?
Where is the post that came from Montague?

sp.speaker: Second Messenger
sp.l: By this at Daintry, with a puissant troop. Enter SIR JOHN SOMERVILLE.

sp.speaker: Warwick
sp.l: Say, Somerville, what says my loving son?
And, by thy guess, how nigh is Clarence now?

sp.speaker: Somerset
sp.l: At Southam I did leave him with his forces,
And do expect him here some two hours hence. Drum heard.

sp.speaker: Warwick
sp.l: Then Clarence is at hand; I hear his drum.

sp.speaker: Somerset
sp.l: It is not his, my lord; here Southam lies:
The drum your honour hears marcheth from Warwick.

sp.speaker: Warwick
sp.l: Who should that be? belike, unlooked-for friends.

sp.speaker: Somerset
sp.l: They are at hand, and you shall quickly know. March: flourish. Enter KING EDWARD, GLOUCESTER, and soldiers.

sp.speaker: King Edward
sp.l: Go, trumpet, to the walls, and sound a parle.

sp.speaker: Gloucester
sp.l: See how the surly Warwick mans the wall!

sp.speaker: Warwick
sp.l: O unbid spite! is sportful Edward come?
Where slept our scouts, or how are they seduced,
That we could hear no news of his repair?

sp.speaker: King Edward
sp.l: Now, Warwick, wilt thou ope the city-gates?
Speak gentle words and humbly bend thy knee,
Call Edward king and at his hands beg mercy?
And he shall pardon thee these outrages.

sp.speaker: Warwick
sp.l: Nay, rather, wilt thou draw thy forces hence,
Confess who set thee up and plucked thee down,
Call Warwick patron and be penitent?
And thou shalt still remain the Duke of York.

sp.speaker: Gloucester
sp.l: I thought, at least, he would have said the king;
Or did he make the jest against his will?

sp.speaker: Warwick
sp.l: Is not a dukedom, sir, a goodly gift?

sp.speaker: Gloucester
sp.l: Ay, by my faith, for a poor earl to give:
I'll do thee service for so good a gift.

sp.speaker: Warwick
sp.l: 'Twas I that gave the kingdom to thy brother.

sp.speaker: King Edward
sp.l: Why then 'tis mine, if but by Warwick's gift.

sp.speaker: Warwick
sp.l: Thou art no Atlas for so great a weight:
And, weakling, Warwick takes his gift again;
And Henry is my king, Warwick his subject.

sp.speaker: King Edward
sp.l: But Warwick's king is Edward's prisoner:
And, gallant Warwick, do but answer this:
What is the body when the head is off?

sp.speaker: Gloucester
sp.l: Alas, that Warwick had no more forecast,
But, whiles he thought to steal the single ten,
The king was slily fingered from the deck!
You left poor Henry at the Bishop's palace,
And, ten to one, you'll meet him in the Tower.

sp.speaker: King Edward
sp.l: 'Tis even so; yet you are Warwick still.

sp.speaker: Gloucester
sp.l: Come, Warwick, take the time; kneel down, kneel down:
Nay, when? strike now, or else the iron cools.

sp.speaker: Warwick
sp.l: I had rather chop this hand off at a blow,
And with the other fling it at thy face,
Than bear so low a sail, to strike to thee.

sp.speaker: King Edward
sp.l: Sail how thou canst, have wind and tide thy friend,
This hand, fast wound about thy coal-black hair,
Shall, whiles thy head is warm and new cut off,
Write in the dust this sentence with thy blood,
“Wind-changing Warwick now can change no more.” Enter OXFORD, with drum and colours.

sp.speaker: Warwick
sp.l: O cheerful colours! see where Oxford comes!

sp.speaker: Oxford
sp.l: Oxford, Oxford, for Lancaster! He and his forces enter the city.

sp.speaker: Gloucester
sp.l: The gates are open, let us enter too.

sp.speaker: King Edward
sp.l: So other foes may set upon our backs.
Stand we in good array: for they no doubt
Will issue out again and bid us battle:
If not, the city being but of small defence,
We'll quickly rouse the traitors in the same.

sp.speaker: Warwick
sp.l: O, welcome, Oxford! for we want thy help. Enter MONTAGUE, with drum and colours.

sp.speaker: Montague
sp.l: Montague, Montague, for Lancaster! He and his forces enter the city.

sp.speaker: Gloucester
sp.l: Thou and thy brother both shall buy this treason
Even with the dearest blood your bodies bear.

sp.speaker: King Edward
sp.l: The harder matched, the greater victory:
My mind presageth happy gain and conquest. Enter SOMERSET, with drum and colours.

sp.speaker: Somerset
sp.l: Somerset, Somerset, for Lancaster! He and his forces enter the city.

sp.speaker: Gloucester
sp.l: Two of thy name, both Dukes of Somerset,
Have sold their lives unto the house of York;
And thou shalt be the third, if this sword hold. Enter CLARENCE, with drum and colours.

sp.speaker: Warwick
sp.l: And lo, where George of Clarence sweeps along,
Of force enough to bid his brother battle;
With whom an upright zeal to right prevails
More than the nature of a brother's love!
Come, Clarence, come; thou wilt, if Warwick call.

sp.speaker: Clarence
sp.l: Father of Warwick, know you what this means? Taking his red rose out of his hat.
Look here, I throw my infamy at thee:
I will not ruinate my father's house,
Who gave his blood to lime the stones together,
And set up Lancaster. Why, trow'st thou, Warwick,
That Clarence is so harsh, so blunt; unnatural,
To bend the fatal instruments of war
Against his brother and his lawful king?
Perhaps thou wilt object my holy oath:
To keep that oath were more impiety
Than Jephthah, when he sacrificed his daughter.
I am so sorry for my trespass made
That, to deserve well at my brother's hands,
I here proclaim myself thy mortal foe,
With resolution, wheresoe'er I meet thee —
As I will meet thee, if thou stir abroad —
To plague thee for thy foul misleading me.
And so, proud-hearted Warwick, I defy thee,
And to my brother turn my blushing cheeks.
Pardon me, Edward, I will make amends:
And, Richard, do not frown upon my faults,
For I will henceforth be no more unconstant.

sp.speaker: King Edward
sp.l: Now welcome more, and ten times more beloved,
Than if thou never hadst deserved our hate.

sp.speaker: Gloucester
sp.l: Welcome, good Clarence; this is brother-like.

sp.speaker: Warwick
sp.l: O passing traitor, perjured and unjust!

sp.speaker: King Edward
sp.l: What, Warwick, wilt thou leave the town and fight?
Or shall we beat the stones about thine ears?

sp.speaker: Warwick
sp.l: Alas, I am not cooped here for defence
I will away towards Barnet presently,
And bid thee battle, Edward, if thou darest.

sp.speaker: King Edward
sp.l: Yes, Warwick, Edward dares, and leads the way.
Lords, to the field; Saint George and victory! Exeunt King Edward and his company, March. Warwick and his company follow.

div.head: Act 5, Scene 2
div.stage: A field of battle near Barnet.
Alarum and excursions. Enter KING EDWARD, bringing forth WARWICK wounded.

sp.speaker: King Edward
sp.l: So, lie thou there: die thou, and die our fear;
For Warwick was a bug that feared us all.
Now, Montague, sit fast; I seek for thee,
That Warwick's bones may keep thine company. Exit.

sp.speaker: Warwick
sp.l: Ah, who is nigh? come to me, friend or foe,
And tell me who is victor, York or Warwick?
Why ask I that? my mangled body shows,
My blood, my want of strength, my sick heart shows,
That I must yield my body to the earth
And, by my fall, the conquest to my foe.
Thus yields the cedar to the axe's edge,
Whose arms gave shelter to the princely eagle,
Under whose shade the ramping lion slept,
Whose top-branch overpeered Jove's spreading tree
And kept low shrubs from winter's powerful wind.
These eyes, that now are dimmed with death's black veil,
Have been as piercing as the midday sun,
To search the secret treasons of the world:
The wrinkles in my brows, now filled with blood,
Were likened oft to kingly sepulchres;
For who lived king, but I could dig his grave?
And who durst smile when Warwick bent his brow?
Lo, now my glory smeared in dust and blood!
My parks, my walks, my manors that I had,
Even now forsake me, and of all my lands
Is nothing left me but my body's length.
Why, what is pomp, rule, reign, but earth and dust?
And, live we how we can, yet die we must. Enter OXFORD and SOMERSET.

sp.speaker: Somerset
sp.l: Ah, Warwick, Warwick! wert thou as we are,
We might recover all our loss again:
The queen from France hath brought a puissant power:
Even now we heard the news; ah, couldst thou fly!

sp.speaker: Warwick
sp.l: Why, then I would not fly. Ah, Montague,
If thou be there, sweet brother, take my hand,
And with thy lips keep in my soul awhile!
Thou lovest me not; for, brother, if thou didst
Thy tears would wash this cold congealed blood
That glues my lips and will not let me speak.
Come quickly, Montague, or I am dead.

sp.speaker: Somerset
sp.l: Ah, Warwick! Montague hath breathed his last;
And to the latest gasp cried out for Warwick
And said “Commend me to my valiant brother. “
And more he would have said, and more he spoke,
Which sounded like a cannon in a vault,
That mought not be distinguished; but at last
I well might hear, delivered with a groan,
“O, farewell, Warwick!”

sp.speaker: Warwick
sp.l: Sweet rest his soul! Fly, lords, and save yourselves;
For Warwick bids you all farewell, to meet in heaven. Dies.

sp.speaker: Oxford
sp.l: Away, away, to meet the queen's great power! Here they bear away his body. Exeunt.

div.head: Act 5, Scene 3
div.stage: Flourish. Enter KING EDWARD in triumph; with GLOUCESTER, CLARENCE, and the rest.

sp.speaker: King Edward
sp.l: Thus far our fortune keeps an upward course,
And we are graced with wreaths of victory.
But, in the midst of this bright-shining day,
I spy a black, suspicious, threatening cloud,
That will encounter with our glorious sun,
Ere he attain his easeful western bed:
I mean, my lords, those powers that the queen
Hath raised in Gallia have arrived our coast
And, as we hear, march on to fight with us.

sp.speaker: Clarence
sp.l: A little gale will soon disperse that cloud
And blow it to the source from whence it came:
Thy very beams will dry those vapours up,
For every cloud engenders not a storm.

sp.speaker: Gloucester
sp.l: The queen is valued thirty thousand strong,
And Somerset, with Oxford, fled to her:
If she have time to breathe, be well assured
Her faction will be full as strong as ours.

sp.speaker: King Edward
sp.l: We are advertised by our loving friends
That they do hold their course toward Tewksbury:
We, having now the best at Barnet field,
Will thither straight, for willingness rids way;
And, as we march, our strength will be augmented
In every county as we go along.
Strike up the drum; cry “Courage!” and away. Exeunt.

div.head: Act 5, Scene 4
div.stage: March. Enter QUEEN MARGARET, PRINCE EDWARD, SOMERSET, OXFORD, and soldiers.

sp.speaker: Queen Margaret
sp.l: Great lords, wise men ne'er sit and wail their loss,
But cheerly seek how to redress their harms.
What though the mast be now blown overboard,
The cable broke, the holding-anchor lost,
And half our sailors swallowed in the flood?
Yet lives our pilot still. Is't meet that he
Should leave the helm and like a fearful lad
With tearful eyes add water to the sea
And give more strength to that which hath too much,
Whiles, in his moan, the ship splits on the rock,
Which industry and courage might have saved?
Ah, what a shame! ah, what a fault were this!
Say Warwick was our anchor; what of that?
And Montague our topmast; what of him?
Our slaughtered friends the tackles; what of these?
Why, is not Oxford here another anchor?
And Somerset another goodly mast?
The friends of France our shrouds and tacklings?
And, though unskilful, why not Ned and I
For once allowed the skilful pilot's charge?
We will not from the helm to sit and weep,
But keep our course, though the rough wind say no,
From shelves and rocks that threaten us with wrack.
As good to chide the waves as speak them fair.
And what is Edward but a ruthless sea?
What Clarence but a quicksand of deceit?
And Richard but a ragged fatal rock?
All these the enemies to our poor bark.
Say you can swim; alas, 'tis but awhile!
Tread on the sand; why, there you quickly sink:
Bestride the rock; the tide will wash you off,
Or else you famish; that's a threefold death.
This speak I, lords, to let you understand,
If case some one of you would fly from us,
That there's no hoped-for mercy with the brothers
More than with ruthless waves, with sands and rocks.
Why, courage then! what cannot be avoided
'Twere childish weakness to lament or fear.

sp.speaker: Edward
sp.l: Methinks a woman of this valiant spirit
Should, if a coward heard her speak these words,
Infuse his breast with magnanimity
And make him, naked, foil a man at arms.
I speak not this as doubting any here;
For did I but suspect a fearful man,
He should have leave to go away betimes,
Lest in our need he might infect another
And make him of like spirit to himself.
If any such be here — as God forbid! —
Let him depart before we need his help.

sp.speaker: Oxford
sp.l: Women and children of so high a courage,
And warriors faint! why, 'twere perpetual shame.
O brave young prince thy famous grandfather
Doth live again in thee: long mayst thou live
To bear his image and renew his glories!

sp.speaker: Somerset
sp.l: And he that will not fight for such a hope,
Go home to bed, and like the owl by day,
If he arise, be mocked and wondered at.

sp.speaker: Queen Margaret
sp.l: Thanks, gentle Somerset; sweet Oxford, thanks.

sp.speaker: Edward
sp.l: And take his thanks that yet hath nothing else. Enter a Messenger.

sp.speaker: Messenger
sp.l: Prepare you, lords, for Edward is at hand,
Ready to fight; therefore be resolute.

sp.speaker: Oxford
sp.l: I thought no less: it is his policy
To haste thus fast, to find us unprovided.

sp.speaker: Somerset
sp.l: But he's deceived; we are in readiness.

sp.speaker: Queen Margaret
sp.l: This cheers my heart, to see your forwardness.

sp.speaker: Oxford
sp.l: Here pitch our battle; hence we will not budge. Flourish and march. Enter KING EDWARD, GLOUCESTER, CLARENCE, and soldiers.

sp.speaker: King Edward
sp.l: Brave followers, yonder stands the thorny wood,
Which, by the heavens' assistance and your strength,
Must by the roots be hewn up yet ere night.
I need not add more fuel to your fire,
For well I wot ye blaze to burn them out:
Give signal to the fight, and to it, lords!

sp.speaker: Queen Margaret
sp.l: Lords, knights, and gentlemen, what I should say
My tears gainsay; for every word I speak,
Ye see, I drink the water of my eye.
Therefore, no more but this: Henry, your sovereign,
Is prisoner to the foe; his state usurped,
His realm a slaughterhouse, his subjects slain,
His statutes cancelled and his treasure spent;
And yonder is the wolf that makes this spoil.
You fight in justice: then, in God's name, lords,
Be valiant and give signal to the fight. Alarum: Retreat: Excursions. Exeunt.

div.head: Act 5, Scene 5
div.stage: Flourish. Enter KING EDWARD, GLOUCESTER, CLARENCE, and soldiers; with QUEEN MARGARET, OXFORD, and SOMERSET, prisoners.

sp.speaker: King Edward
sp.l: Now here a period of tumultuous broils.
Away with Oxford to Hames Castle straight:
For Somerset, off with his guilty head.
Go, bear them hence; I will not hear them speak.

sp.speaker: Oxford
sp.l: For my part, I'll not trouble thee with words,

sp.speaker: Somerset
sp.l: Nor I, but stoop with patience to my fortune. Exeunt Oxford and Somerset, guarded.

sp.speaker: Queen Margaret
sp.l: So part we sadly in this troublous world,
To meet with joy in sweet Jerusalem.

sp.speaker: King Edward
sp.l: Is proclamation made, that who finds Edward
Shall have a high reward, and he his life?

sp.speaker: Gloucester
sp.l: It is: and lo, where youthful Edward comes! Enter soldiers, with PRINCE EDWARD.

sp.speaker: King Edward
sp.l: Bring forth the gallant, let us hear him speak.
What! can so young a thorn begin to prick?
Edward, what satisfaction canst thou make
For bearing arms, for stirring up my subjects,
And all the trouble thou hast turned me to?

sp.speaker: Edward
sp.l: Speak like a subject, proud ambitious York!
Suppose that I am now my father's mouth;
Resign thy chair, and where I stand kneel thou,
Whilst I propose the selfsame words to thee,
Which, traitor, thou wouldst have me answer to.

sp.speaker: Queen Margaret
sp.l: Ah, that thy father had been so resolved!

sp.speaker: Gloucester
sp.l: That you might still have worn the petticoat,
And ne'er have stol'n the breech from Lancaster.

sp.speaker: Edward
sp.l: Let AEsop fable in a winter's night;
His currish riddles sorts not with this place.

sp.speaker: Gloucester
sp.l: By heaven, brat, I'll plague ye for that word.

sp.speaker: Queen Margaret
sp.l: Ay, thou wast born to be a plague to men.

sp.speaker: Gloucester
sp.l: For God's sake, take away this captive scold.

sp.speaker: Edward
sp.l: Nay, take away this scolding crookback rather.

sp.speaker: King Edward
sp.l: Peace, wilful boy, or I will charm your tongue.

sp.speaker: Clarence
sp.l: Untutored lad, thou art too malapert.

sp.speaker: Edward
sp.l: I know my duty; you are all undutiful:
Lascivious Edward, and thou perjured George,
And thou misshapen Dick, I tell ye all
I am your better, traitors as ye are:
And thou usurp'st my father's right and mine.

sp.speaker: King Edward
sp.l: Take that, the likeness of this railer here. Stabs him.

sp.speaker: Gloucester
sp.l: Sprawl'st thou? take that, to end thy agony. Stabs him.

sp.speaker: Clarence
sp.l: And there's for twitting me with perjury. Stabs him.

sp.speaker: Queen Margaret
sp.l: O, kill me too!

sp.speaker: Gloucester
sp.l: Marry, and shall. Offers to kill her.

sp.speaker: King Edward
sp.l: Hold, Richard, hold; for we have done too much.

sp.speaker: Gloucester
sp.l: Why should she live, to fill the world with words?

sp.speaker: King Edward
sp.l: What, doth she swoon? use means for her recovery.

sp.speaker: Gloucester
sp.l: Clarence, excuse me to the king my brother;
I'll hence to London on a serious matter:
Ere ye come there, be sure to hear some news.

sp.speaker: Clarence
sp.l: What? what?

sp.speaker: Gloucester
sp.l: The Tower, the Tower. Exit.

sp.speaker: Queen Margaret
sp.l: O Ned, sweet Ned! speak to thy mother, boy!
Canst thou not speak? O traitors! murderers!
They that stabbed Caesar shed no blood at all,
Did not offend, nor were not worthy blame,
If this foul deed were by to equal it:
He was a man; this, in respect, a child:
And men ne'er spend their fury on a child.
What's worse than murderer, that I may name it?
No, no, my heart will burst, an if I speak:
And I will speak, that so my heart may burst.
Butchers and villains! bloody cannibals!
How sweet a plant have you untimely cropped!
You have no children, butchers! if you had,
The thought of them would have stirred up remorse:
But if you ever chance to have a child,
Look in his youth to have him so cut off
As, deathsmen, you have rid this sweet young prince!

sp.speaker: King Edward
sp.l: Away with her; go, bear her hence perforce.

sp.speaker: Queen Margaret
sp.l: Nay, never bear me hence, dispatch me here;
Here sheathe thy sword, I'll pardon thee my death:
What, wilt thou not? then, Clarence, do it thou.

sp.speaker: Clarence
sp.l: By heaven, I will not do thee so much ease.

sp.speaker: Queen Margaret
sp.l: Good Clarence, do; sweet Clarence, do thou do it.

sp.speaker: Clarence
sp.l: Didst thou not hear me swear I would not do it?

sp.speaker: Queen Margaret
sp.l: Ay, but thou usest to forswear thyself:
'Twas sin before, but now 'tis charity.
What, wilt thou not? Where is that devil's butcher,
Hard-favoured Richard? Richard, where art thou?
Thou art not here: murder is thy alms-deed;
Petitioners for blood thou ne'er put'st back.

sp.speaker: King Edward
sp.l: Away, I say; I charge ye, bear her hence.

sp.speaker: Queen Margaret
sp.l: So come to you and yours, as to this prince! Exit, led out forcibly.

sp.speaker: King Edward
sp.l: Where's Richard gone?

sp.speaker: Clarence
sp.l: To London, all in post; and, as I guess,
To make a bloody supper in the Tower.

sp.speaker: King Edward
sp.l: He's sudden, if a thing comes in his head.
Now march we hence: discharge the common sort
With pay and thanks, and let's away to London
And see our gentle queen how well she fares:
By this, I hope, she hath a son for me. Exeunt.

div.head: Act 5, Scene 6
div.stage: Enter KING HENRY and GLOUCESTER, with the Lieutenant, on the walls.

sp.speaker: Gloucester
sp.l: Good day, my lord: What, at your book so hard?

sp.speaker: King Henry
sp.l: Ay, my good lord: — my lord, I should say rather;
'Tis sin to flatter; “good” was little better:
“Good Gloucester” and “good devil” were alike.
And both preposterous; therefore, not “good lord.”

sp.speaker: Gloucester
sp.l: Sirrah, leave us to ourselves: we must confer. Exit Lieutenant.

sp.speaker: King Henry
sp.l: So flies the reckless shepherd from the wolf;
So first the harmless sheep doth yield his fleece
And next his throat unto the butcher's knife.
What scene of death hath Roscius now to act?

sp.speaker: Gloucester
sp.l: Suspicion always haunts the guilty mind;
The thief doth fear each bush an officer.

sp.speaker: King Henry
sp.l: The bird that hath been limed in a bush,
With trembling wings misdoubteth every bush;
And I, the hapless male to one sweet bird,
Have now the fatal object in my eye
Where my poor young was limed, was caught and killed.

sp.speaker: Gloucester
sp.l: Why, what a peevish fool was that of Crete,
That taught his son the office of a fowl!
And yet, for all his wings, the fool was drowned.

sp.speaker: King Henry
sp.l: I, Daedalus; my poor boy, Icarus;
Thy father, Minos, that denied our course;
The sun that seared the wings of my sweet boy
Thy brother Edward, and thyself the sea
Whose envious gulf did swallow up his life.
Ah, kill me with thy weapon, not with words!
My breast can better brook thy dagger's point
Than can my ears that tragic history.
But wherefore dost thou come? is't for my life?

sp.speaker: Gloucester
sp.l: Think'st thou I am an executioner?

sp.speaker: King Henry
sp.l: A persecutor, I am sure, thou art:
If murdering innocents be executing,
Why, then thou art an executioner.

sp.speaker: Gloucester
sp.l: Thy son I killed for his presumption.

sp.speaker: King Henry
sp.l: Hadst thou been killed when first thou didst presume,
Thou hadst not lived to kill a son of mine.
And thus I prophesy, that many a thousand,
Which now mistrust no parcel of my fear,
And many an old man's sigh and many a widow's,
And many an orphan's water-standing eye —
Men for their sons, wives for their husbands,
Orphans for their parents' timeless death —
Shall rue the hour that ever thou wast born.
The owl shrieked at thy birth, — an evil sign;
The night-crow cried, aboding luckless time;
Dogs howled, and hideous tempest shook down trees;
The raven rooked her on the chimney's top,
And chattering pies in dismal discords sung.
Thy mother felt more than a mother's pain,
And yet brought forth less than a mother's hope,
To wit, an indigested and deformed lump,
Not like the fruit of such a goodly tree,
Teeth hadst thou in thy head when thou wast born,
To signify thou camest to bite the world:
And, if the rest be true which I have heard,
Thou camest —

sp.speaker: Gloucester
sp.l: I'll hear no more: die, prophet, in thy speech: Stabs him.
For this, amongst the rest, was I ordained.

sp.speaker: King Henry
sp.l: Ay, and for much more slaughter after this.
O, God forgive my sins, and pardon thee! Dies.

sp.speaker: Gloucester
sp.l: What, will the aspiring blood of Lancaster
Sink in the ground? I thought it would have mounted.
See how my sword weeps for the poor king's death!
O, may such purple tears be alway shed
From those that wish the downfall of our house!
If any spark of life be yet remaining,
Down, down to hell; and say I sent thee thither: Stabs him again.
I, that have neither pity, love, nor fear.
Indeed, 'tis true that Henry told me of;
For I have often heard my mother say
I came into the world with my legs forward:
Had I not reason, think ye, to make haste,
And seek their ruin that usurped our right?
The midwife wondered and the women cried
“O, Jesus bless us, he is born with teeth”
And so I was; which plainly signified
That I should snarl and bite and play the dog.
Then, since the heavens have shaped my body so,
Let hell make crooked my mind to answer it.
I have no brother, I am like no brother;
And this word “love,” which greybeards call divine,
Be resident in men like one another
And not in me: I am myself alone.
Clarence, beware; thou keep'st me from the light:
But I will sort a pitchy day for thee;
For I will buzz abroad such prophecies
That Edward shall be fearful of his life,
And then, to purge his fear, I'll be thy death.
King Henry and the prince his son are gone:
Clarence, thy turn is next, and then the rest,
Counting myself but bad till I be best.
I'll throw thy body in another room
And triumph, Henry, in thy day of doom. Exit with the body.

div.head: Act 5, Scene 7
div.stage: Flourish. Enter KING EDWARD, QUEEN ELIZABETH, CLARENCE, GLOUCESTER, HASTINGS, a Nurse with the young Prince, and Attendants.

sp.speaker: King Edward
sp.l: Once more we sit in England's royal throne,
Repurchased with the blood of enemies.
What valiant foemen, like to autumn's corn,
Have we mowed down in tops of all their pride!
Three Dukes of Somerset, threefold renowned
For hardy and undoubted champions;
Two Cliffords, as the father and the son,
And two Northumberlands; two braver men
Ne'er spurred their coursers at the trumpet's sound;
With them, the two brave bears, Warwick and Montague,
That in their chains fettered the kingly lion
And made the forest tremble when they roared.
Thus have we swept suspicion from our seat
And made our footstool of security.
Come hither, Bess, and let me kiss my boy.
Young Ned, for thee, thine uncles and myself
Have in our armours watched the winter's night,
Went all afoot in summer's scalding heat,
That thou mightst repossess the crown in peace;
And of our labours thou shalt reap the gain.

sp.speaker: Gloucester
sp.l: I'll blast his harvest, if your head were laid;
For yet I am not looked on in the world.
This shoulder was ordained so thick to heave;
And heave it shall some weight, or break my back:
Work thou the way, — and thou shalt execute.

sp.speaker: King Edward
sp.l: Clarence and Gloucester, love my lovely queen;
And kiss your princely nephew, brothers both.

sp.speaker: Clarence
sp.l: The duty that I owe unto your majesty
I seal upon the lips of this sweet babe.

sp.speaker: Queen Elizabeth
sp.l: Thanks, noble Clarence; worthy brother, thanks.

sp.speaker: Gloucester
sp.l: And, that I love the tree from whence thou sprang'st,
Witness the loving kiss I give the fruit. Aside
To say the truth, so Judas kissed his master,
And cried “all hail!” when as he meant all harm.

sp.speaker: King Edward
sp.l: Now am I seated as my soul delights,
Having my country's peace and brothers' loves.

sp.speaker: Clarence
sp.l: What will your grace have done with Margaret?
Reignier, her father, to the king of France
Hath pawned the Sicils and Jerusalem,
And hither have they sent it for her ransom.

sp.speaker: King Edward
sp.l: Away with her, and waft her hence to France.
And now what rests but that we spend the time
With stately triumphs, mirthful comic shows,
Such as befits the pleasure of the court?
Sound drums and trumpets! farewell sour annoy!
For here, I hope, begins our lasting joy. Exeunt.
